patient_information: 31-year-old man from Guatemala, no past medical history.
chief_complaint: Acute weakness and numbness of the leg.
history_of_present_illness: Presented to a hospital in New York City with several minutes of weakness and numbness of the leg, which resolved just before his arrival. Two weeks previously, he also had two 10-second episodes of facial twitching that subsided without intervention.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Born and lived in a rural area of Guatemala before immigrating to New York 5 years ago. In Guatemala, his family owned uncorralled pigs, and his house lacked sanitation services.
physical_exam: Cranial nerves intact. Motor and sensory examinations normal. Deep tendon reflexes and gait normal. Rest of the exam unremarkable.
labs_and_diagnostics: Cell blood count and serum chemistry were within normal limits. CT scan and MRI on admission revealed parenchymal calcified lesions, complex cystic structures in the subarachnoid space, and an old lacunar infarct proximal to a cyst. A CT angiography showed patent cerebral arteries. Serum immunoblot for cysticercosis (CDC) was positive. Serum cysticercosis antigen was positive. Spine MRI did not show evidence of spinal involvement.
management_and_clinical_course: Patient was started on a high dose of prednisone followed by a taper, and dual therapy with albendazole and praziquantel. After 9 months of treatment, his serum antigen was negative, and his lesions resolved on imaging. He has been followed closely with no recurrence.
